comments.commentBody: Adblock is good. However, today, they put pictures of cats where the ads would be, instead of just removing the ads. When I clicked on one of the cat pictures, it gave me the option of removing the cats, which I did. It also said April Fool from Adblock. Sort of cute, but I'm glad they only do stuff like that once a year.

I don't know how typical I am, but I really don't see many ads, even though I have the TV on in most of the TV viewing hours. My primary information medium is reading, either through the internet or dead tree medium. When I do have the TV on I also have something to read on my lap. That's how I read most of the Washington Post, hard copy delivered, and the NYT, digital on ipad. When they are on I have a book on my lap. If I'm interested in a show I'll watch until an ad comes on and then switch to the alternative medium . My wife doe the same. We both have internet devices besides so even a compelling shows loses us temporarily when the ads come up.
It isn't hard to do this since the sound (either pitch or volume) always changes when the ads appear.

To JDKJJK: This response should have come first -- don't really understand why, but it wasn't published when I originally sent it, at about 1:30 AM.

You misunderstand. I don't favor the Ryan budget ... and I'm not even sure Ryan does (despite his 98-page manifesto in support of it). While I believe we need to dramatically lower federal expenditures (of which, currently 40% is new debt), I don't believe we can accomplish it in one budget, or even five, without causing untold hardship; and I don't believe we can bring our deficits under control without some higher taxes.

But if your objective is to rein in deficit spending and keep taxes to a minimum, objectives I DO support, then you have to start somewhere; and in a negotiation with spendthrifts whose primary argument is "look at how much misery there is out there -- how can you begrudge the federal government every dime you earn in order to alleviate it?", then the starting point in the dickering from the sensible side needs to be scary-right.

But if your personal position is that there's no point in seeking compromises, then you've already been suckered in the negotiation.

EXPECT the Republicans to use the proffered budget as a negotiating tool; and if they can't excite sensible responses from the left because the Senate won't cooperate, fine: there's always what Dr. Krugman derides as renewed debt-ceiling Armageddons on Mr. Obama's watch.

Mr. Luettgen

My use of the term treason is outside the definition of the Article 3 but I can claim I am engaging in the same hyperbole as the Republicans who claim Obama is the greatest threat to American liberty in American History.
My apologies for believing you endorsed the Ryan Plan, as I have read your comments in the past and find most of your arguments lucid and sometimes I even agree with them. However, I still do not believe the Ryan Plan is a starting point for negotiations. The Republicans have consistently demonstrated that they have no intention of negotiating with Obama and their main goal is not what is in the best interests of the nation but how can we ensure Obama's defeat.
One look no further than the Repubican Icon, Dick Cheney, who famously stated that Reagan proved deficts do not matter, which drew very little criticism from the party base, to the current stance of the Republican Party who accuses Obama of turning the US into Greece.

So you have just agreed that Ryan plan is fraudulent. Political document designed to fool American people and win a skirmish with Dems.

No real policy value!

Ryan's budget may serve two purposes, since it is: 1) the first detailed proposal allowing counter-offers that are at central to compromises; and 2) sufficiently scary to liberals to force a pause in the endless cries over the "Bush tax cuts" -- if Ryan's proffer is even more draconian than Bush's tax cuts, perhaps then they may become less important as bargaining chips in the inevitable budgetary dickering.

And the Ryan budget is two MORE things: 1) more than the Democrats ever accomplished in the last Congress, as they never produced a budget at all, despite a majority in BOTH houses of Congress, and holding the White House; and 2) even more disingenuous than claimed, because American taxpayers (individuals as well as businesses) are not going to tolerate the loss of "loop holes", because they simply don't trust even a conservative Congress -- let Congress eliminate "loop holes", and all you have left are the naked marginal rates, without the deductions; and then you watch another, perhaps more liberal Congress, start to raise them, having lost your only protection from the predation. Ain't gonna happen.

If liberals had sense, they'd deliver a full-blown counter-budget that advances their own priorities and methods for funding them. But because of the severity of Ryan's, he's already won big, as any such counter inevitably will be pulled to the right. But if liberals do nothing but kvetch, they'll be relegated to the role of complainers while they get steamrolled.

Joe Biden made an interesting comment on Face the Nation today.  I've heard others echo these thoughts as well, and that is that there is at least one positive thing to come out this election cycle, and that is the Republicans are for once stating their actual beliefs -- that if you get sick and don't have insurance we as a society should just let you die; that women should not be given access to basic reproductive health care unless they can afford it; that public schools should be defunded; that it's perfectly OK for the wealthiest Americans to pay 1/2 the percentage of income taxes as the rest of us; etc., etc.  Once these facts make their way out of the echo chamber, we can only hope that the GOP has lost all credibility among the American People.  A new party is needed -- the GOP needs to go the way of the Whigs.
Don't sit and watch the show and shake your head. Get up in the faces of your own elected representatives; support candidates that are better, even by an inch, than the ones elected last time around.

I see our political system like a cancer. Every year things get worse, but eventually it will kill you. Nothing here, just move along. No one is admitting we have grave problems that have to be dealt with. Passing the buck only means impending third world status.

The status quo is alive and well. Corporations hate uncertainty and will pull the strings to get whatever they want at our nation’s expense. We no longer live in a Democracy for the people, by the people. Money/greed/power combined with no compassion/morals on the other side have usurped the decency that made this nation great.

50% or more of our nation has no clue what’s happening to them. They blindly latch on to the vitriol/hatred spewed from the other side keeping our nation in fear and preventing any real progress.

I and many others sit and watch as our nation falls into abysmal decline - shaking our heads in utter amazement as to why no one has seized the moment to lay bare all the lies and propaganda we see and hear every day. Alas, the media is part of the problem.

Instead, this roller coaster is careening off the tracks into Third world status. Maybe then, people will demand what they lost.

In the German model, does each employee pay the same amount for their insurance? I thought Prof. Reinhardt mentioned something about it being a fixed percentage of one's salary.

Plus, if you switch jobs, or become unemployed, do you have to switch insurers? Does the employer get to determine which insurer and which benefits you receive? Are they responsible for negotiating the cost of benefits? Does the size of the company matter? Don't Germans buy insurance for an individual person? Aren't children insured through a separate mechanism altogether?

We also pay for Medicare via payroll taxes to which employers contribute. But nobody calls that employer based simply because it is funded by taxes on employees.

Is the funding of insurance via the employer really the most salient feature of the German system? Does any country other than ours leave it up to the employer to determine what benefit package we receive?

Isn't it the case that our employer based healthcare system has as many significant differences as commonalities with the German based system? Aren't we talking about superficial things in common?

If people who understand healthcare make such superficial comparisons in explaining our system, how can anyone blame the public for not understanding the issues?
